acme.example: The new Cessna airplanes will be the acme of comfort, offering reclining seats and ample legroom.

advocate.example: While the senator privately approved of gay marriage, he was unwilling to advocate for the cause in a public venue.
advocate.meaning: speak, plead, or argue in favor of
advocate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

advocate.example: Martin Luther King Jr. was a tireless advocate for the rights of African-Americans in the United States.
advocate.meaning: a person who pleads for a cause or propounds an idea
advocate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

affluent.example: The center of the city had sadly become a pit of penury, while, only five miles away, multi-million dollar homes spoke of affluence.

altruism.example: Albert Schweitzer spent most of his life doing missionary work as a doctor in Africa, seeking no reward, apparently motivated only by altruism.

amiable.example: Amy's name was very apt: she was so amiable that she was twice voted class president.

analogous.example: In many ways, the Internet's transformative effect on society has been analogous to that of the printing press.
analogous.meaning: similar in some respects but otherwise different

animosity.example: The governor's animosity toward his rival was only inflamed when the latter spread false lies regarding the governor's first term.

antiquated.example: Aunt Betty had antiquated notions about marriage, believing that a man should court a woman for at least a year before receiving a kiss.

apex.example: The Ivy League is considered the apex of the secondary education system.

appreciable.example: There is an appreciable difference between those who say they can get the job done and those who actually get the job done.

archaic.example: Hoping to sound intelligent, Mary spoke in archaic English that was right out of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice - needless to say, she didn't have many friends.

autonomously.example: Many of the factory workers are worried about being replaced by machines and computers that will work completely autonomously.
autonomously.meaning: in a self-governing and independent manner

avert.example: Afraid to see the aftermath of the car crash, I averted my eyes as we drove by.
The struggling videogame company put all of its finances into one final, desperate project to avert bankrupcy.

avid.example: Martin is an avid birdwatcher, often taking long hikes into remote mountains to see some rare eagle.
avid.meaning: showing an acvite interest or enthusiasm for something

balk.example: The students were willing to clean up the broken glass, but when the teacher asked them to mop the entire floor, they balked, citing reasons why they needed to leave.
balk.meaning: foil or thwart, stop short, refuse to go on

banish.example: The most difficult part of the fast was banishing thoughts of food.
banish.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

becoming.example: Her dress was becoming and made her look even more beautiful.
becoming.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

belittle.example: A good teacher will never belittle his students, but will instead empower them.
belittle.meaning: lessen in importance, dismiss as unimportant

buttress.example: China's economy has been buttressed by a global demand for the electronic parts the country manufactures.

candid.example: Even with a perfect stranger, Charles was always candid and would rarely hold anything back.

candidness.example: Although I was unhappy that the relationship ended, I appreciated her candidness about why she was ready to move on from the relationship.
candidness.meaning: the quality of being honest and open

coalesce.example: Over time, the various tribes coalesced into a single common culture with one universal language.
coalesce.meaning_bg: обединявам се, сливам се, сдружавам се

colossal.example: Few appreciate the colossal scale of the sun: if hollow, it could contain a million Earths.

complementary.example: The head waiter was careful to tell the amateur diners that red wine was complementary with beef, each bringing out subtle taste notes in the other.
complementary.meaning: serving to complete something, enhancing each other's qualities

constraint.example: He found pop music a constraint on his ability to learn and preferred to listen to classical musical while studying.

contemptuous.example: Always on the forefront of fashion, Vanessa looked contemptuously at anyone wearing dated clothing.

conundrum.example: Computers have helped solve some of the mathematical conundrums which have puzzled man for many centuries.

convoluted.example: Instead of solving the math problem in three simple steps, Kumar used a convoluted solution requiring fifteen steps.

corroborate.example: Her claim that frog populations were falling precipitously in Central America was corroborated by locals, who reported that many species of frogs had seemingly vanished overnight.

cosmopolitan.example: There are few cities in the world as diverse and cosmopolitan as New York.
cosmopolitan.meaning: including people from many different countries

cumbersome.example: Only ten years ago, being an avid reader and a traveler meant carrying a cumbersome backpack stuffed with books - these days we need only an e-reader.

delegate.example: Since the senior manager had to go on many international business trips, she was forced to delegate many of her responsibilities to two lower-level managers.
delegate.meaning: give an assignment to, entrust task or responsibility to another
delegate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

demean.example: At first the soccer players bantered back and forth, but as soon as one of the players became demeaning, calling the other's mother a water buffalo, the ref whipped out a red card.
demean.meaning: to insult; to cause someone to lose dignity or respect

deride.example: The nun derided the students for trying to sneak insects and worms into the classroom.

desecrate.example: After desecrating the pharaoh's tomb, the archaeologist soon fell victim to a horrible illness.
desecrate.meaning: to willfully violate or destroy a sacred place

detrimental.example: Many know that smoking is detrimental to your health, but processed sugar in large quantities is equally bad.

differentiate.example: Mozart's long melodic lines differentiate his compositions from other works of late 18th century music.
Animals on Madagascar differentiated from other similar animal species due to many years of isolation on the island.
differentiate.meaning: become different in the process of growth or development

diligent.example: Michael was a diligent gardener, never leaving a leaf on the ground and regularly watering each plant.
diligent.meaning: characterized by care and perseverance in carrying out tasks

discriminate.example: Sarah couldn't discriminate between a good wine and a bad wine, so she avoided wine tastings.
discriminate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

disparate.example: With the advent of machines capable of looking inside the brain, fields as disparate as religion and biology have been brought together by scientists trying to understand what happens in the brain when people have a religious experience.

eccentric.example: Mozart was well-known for his eccentricities, often speaking words backward to confuse those around him.

egotist.example: An egotist, Natasha had few friends because of her inability to talk about anything except her dream of becoming the next American Idol.

elaborate.example: Thomas, on returning from Morocco, replaced his dirty gray carpet with an elaborate one he'd brought back with him.
elaborate.meaning: marked by complexity and richness of detail

elaborate.example: Most high school physics teachers find themselves elaborating the same point over and over again, since many concepts confuse students.

elude.example: Even a basic understanding of physics can elude most high schools students.

elusive.example: Many first time skydivers say that describing the act of falling from the sky is elusive.
elusive.meaning: difficult to grasp or remember, evasive

embellish.example: McCartney would write relatively straightforward lyrics, and Lennon would embellish them with puns and poetic images.

emulate.example: To really become fluent in a new language, emulate the speech patterns and intonation of people who speak the language.

enmity.example: Charles rude remark toward Sarah yesterday was due to his illness, not due to any real enmity toward Sarah.

enumerate.example: The survey enumerates the number of happy workers and the number of unhappy workers.
I sat and listened as she enumerated all of the things she did not like about the past three months.

err.example: He erred in thinking that "indigent" and "indignant" were synonyms.

exasperate.example: As a child, I exasperated my mother with strings of never-ending questions.

exemplify.example: Lincoln exemplified the best of not only America, but also the potential greatness that exists within each person.
exemplify.meaning: serve as an example of, embody

exemplify.example: Please present some case studies that exemplify the results that you claim in your paper.
exemplify.meaning: illustrate or clarify by giving an example of

extenuating.example: The jury was hardly moved by the man's plea that his loneliness was an extenuating factor in his crime of dognapping a prized pooch.
extenuating.meaning: making less guilty or more forgivable, mitigating

fawn.example: The media fawned over the handsome new CEO, praising his impeccable sense of style instead of asking more pointed questions.
fawn.meaning: try to gain favor by extreme flattery
fawn.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

futile.example: I thought I could repair the car myself, but after two days of work with no success, I have to admit that my efforts were futile.

impeccable.example: He was impeccably dressed in the latest fashion without a single crease or stain.

impede.example: Since the police sergeant had to train the pair of new hires, progress in his own case was impeded.

implicate.example: By saying that some of the guests were uncomfortable, the manager implicated to the hotel staff that it needed to be more dilligent.
The crime boss was implicated for a long list of crimes, ranging from murder to disturbing the peace.
implicate.meaning: incriminate, show to be involved in a crime

inadvertent.example: Although Prohibition was rooted in noble ideals, the inadvertent and costly consequences of making alcohol illegal in the U.S. led its the repeal.
inadvertent.meaning: unintentional, happening by chance or unexpectedly

inarticulate.example: Although a brilliant economist, Professor Black was completely inarticulate, a terrible lecturer.

incessant.example: I don't mind small children in brief doses, but I think the incessant exposure that their parents have to them would quickly wear me down.
incessant.meaning: unceasing, continuing without pause or interruption

indict.example: The bankrobber was indicted on several major charges, including possession of a firearm.
indict.meaning: to formally charge or accuse of wrong-doing

indigenous.example: The plants and animals indigenous to Australia are notably different from those indigenous to the U.S-one look at a duckbill platypus and you know you're not dealing with an opossum.

indignant.example: When the cyclist swerved into traffic, it forced the driver to brake and elicited an indignant shout of "Hey, punk, watch where you're going!"

inflammable.example: It only takes one person to leave an inflammable comment on an Internet thread for that thread to blow up into pages upon pages of reader indignation.
inflammable.meaning_bg: лесно запалим, възбудим, избухлив; подпалвачески, подстрекателски

insolvent.example: With credit card bills skyrocketing, a shockingly large number of Americans are truly insolvent.
insolvent.meaning: unable to pay one's bills; bankrupt

intermittent.example: The intermittent thunder continued and the night was punctuated by cracks of lightning - a surreal sleepless night.

inundate.example: The newsroom was inundated with false reports that only made it more difficult for the newscasters to provide an objective account of the bank robbery.
inundate.meaning: to flood or overwhelm with things to be dealt with

jocular.example: My uncle was always in a jocular mood at family gatherings, messing up people's hair and telling knockknock jokes to anyone who would listen.

laborious.example: The most laborious job I've had was working 20 hours a day as a fisherman in King Salmon, Alaska.

lethargic.example: Nothing can make a person more lethargic than a big turkey dinner.

lucid.example: Though Walters writes about physics and time travel, his writing is always lucid, so readers with little scientific training can understand difficult concepts.

malodorous.example: Some thermally active fountains spew sulfur fumes - the air around them is sometimes so malodorous that many have to plug their noses.

meander.example: A casual observer might have thought that Peter was meandering through the city, but that day he was actually seeking out those places where he and his long lost love had once visited.

melee.example: After enduring daily taunts about my name, I became enraged and pummeled the schoolyard bully and his sycophantic friends in a brutal melee.
melee.meaning: a wild, confusing fight or struggle

misanthrope.example: Hamilton had been deceived so many times in his life that he hid behind the gruff exterior of a misanthrope, lambasting perfect strangers for no apparent reason.

miser.example: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.
miser.meaning: a person who doesn't like to spend money (because he is greedy)

misogynist.example: Many have accused Hemingway of being a quiet misogynist, but recently unearthed letters argue against this belief.
misogynist.meaning: a person who dislikes women in particular

morose.example: After Stanley found out he was no longer able to go on vacation with his friends, he sat in his room morosely.
morose.meaning: ill-tempered and not inclined to talk; gloomy, sullen

obdurate.example: No number of pleas and bribes would get him to change his obdurate attitude.
obdurate.meaning: stubbornly refusing to change opinion or course of action

obstinate.example: The coach suggested improvements Sarah might make on the balance beam, but she remained obstinate, unwilling to modify any of the habits that made her successful in the past.
obstinate.meaning: resistant to guidance or discipline; stubbornly persistent

ornate.example: The ornate Victorian and Edwardian homes spread throughout San Francisco are my favorite part of the city.

paradoxical.example: That light could be both a particle and a wave seems paradoxical, but nonetheless, it is true.

peevish.example: Our office manager is peevish, so the rest of us tip-toe around him, hoping not to set off another one of his fits.

pinnacle.example: At its pinnacle, the Roman Empire extended across most of the landmass of Eurasia, a feat not paralleled to the rise of the British Empire in the 18th and 19th century.

piquant.example: The chef, with a mere flick of the salt shaker, turned the bland tomato soup into a piquant meal.
piquant.meaning: having a pleasantly sharp taste or appetizing flavor

pithy.example: I enjoy reading the Daodejing for its pithy and insightful prose; it always gives me something to think about.
pithy.meaning: concise and full of meaning, substantial

precedent.example: The principal explained that even though one student had done modelling work outside of school, the outfits that student wore in those photographs in no way established a precedent for what could be worn at school dances.
precedent.meaning: an example used to justify similar occurrences at a later time

preempt.example: A governmental warning about an imminent terrorist attack would preempt ordinary network programming on television.
preempt.meaning: take the place of or have precedence over

preemptive.example: Just as Martha was about to take the only cookie left on the table, Noah preemptively swiped it.
preemptive.meaning: taking action in order to prevent something from happening

presumption.example: When Mr. Baker found out the family car was gone, he acted under the presumption that his rebellious son had taken the car, calling his son's phone and yelling at him; only later did Mr. Baker realize that Mrs. Baker had simply gone out to get her nails d
presumption.meaning: an assumption that is taken for granted

presumption.example: The new neighbor quickly gained a reptuation for her presumption; she had invited herself to several of the neighbors homes, often stopping over at inopportune times and asking for a drink.

profuse.example: During mile 20 of the Hawaii Marathon, Dwayne was sweating so profusely that he stopped to take off his shirt, and ran the remaining six miles wearing nothing more than skimpy shorts.

proponent.example: Ironically, the leading proponent of Flat-Earth Theory flies all over the world in an effort to win more adherents.
proponent.meaning: a person who pleads for a cause or advocates an idea

provisional.example: Until the corporate office hands down a definitive decision on use of the extra offices, we will share their use in a provisional arrangement.
provisional.meaning: arranged for the present and not fully agreed on

quandary.example: Steve certainly is in a quandary: if he doesn't call Elaine, she will blame him for everything, but if he does call her, the evidence of where he currently is could cost him his job.
quandary.meaning: dilemma, state of uncertainty or perplexity over what to do

rash.example: Although Bruce was able to make the delivery in time with a nightime motorcycle ride in the rain, Susan criticized his actions as rash.
rash.meaning: done without careful consideration of the possible consequences; impetuous
rash.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

resolve.example: After much thought, Ted resolved not to travel abroad this summer because he didn't have much money in his bank account.
resolve.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

respite.example: Every afternoon, the small company has a respite in which workers play foosball or board games.
respite.meaning: short rest or relief from work or something difficult or unpleasant

robust.example: Chris preferred bland and mild beers, but Bhavin preferred a beer with more robust flavor.
robust.meaning: sturdy and strong in form or construction

squander.example: Fearing his money would be squandered by his family, he gave all of it to charity when he died.

stipend.example: He was hoping for a monthly allowance loan from the government, but after no such stipend was forthcoming he realized he would have to seek other means of paying for his college tuition.

summit.example: After hiking for two days, the climbers finally reached the summit of Mount Kilimanjaro.
Since climate change policy has been mired in congressional fighting, this summit should help set the goals for president's next term.

tender.example: The government was loath to tender more money in the fear that it might set off inflation.
tender.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

thrifty.example: He was economical, spending his money thriftily and on items considered essential.

thwart.example: I wanted to spend a week in New York this autumn, but the high costs of travel and lodging thwarted my plans.

transitory.example: If we lived forever and life was not transitory, do you think we would appreciate life less or more?

uncanny.example: normal Reggie has an uncanny ability to connect with animals: feral cats will readily approach him, and sometimes even wild birds will land on his finger.

unprecedented.example: When America first created its national parks, the idea of setting aside the most beautiful land in a country was unprecedented in the history of mankind.
unprecedented.meaning: never done or known before, novel

variance.example: The cynic quipped, "There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate".
variance.meaning: the quality of being different and varying

vindictive.example: Though the other girl had only lightly poked fun of Vanessa's choice in attire, Vanessa was so vindictive that she waited for an entire semester to get the perfect revenge.
vindictive.meaning: having a strong desire for revenge

voracious.example: Steven was a voracious reader, sometimes finishing two novels in the same day.
voracious.meaning: very hungry; having a very eager approach to an activity
voracious.meaning_bg: лаком, ненаситен (и в преносен позитивен смисъл)

whimsical.example: Adults look to kids and envy their whimsical nature at times, wishing that they could act without reason and play without limitation.
whimsical.meaning: determined by impulse or whim rather than by reason
